Award.AwardTitle: Signaling, Dyad Formation, and the Encrypted Nature of Group Cohesion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Richard McElreath and Dr. Thomas Flamson will explore the mechanisms that influence human group formation and the means through which group formation are negotiated, maintained, and reformed, a core question in anthropology's mission to theoretically explore the causes, consequences, and complexities of human social and cultural variability. The project will entail a two-year study of the formation of smaller cooperative groups within larger communities, a process often called "assortment." Individuals vary in their goals, desires, and abilities, and successful cooperation often depends upon assortment that respects this variation. This research will be primarily conducted in an agricultural community in Northeastern Brazil, where the changes in community membership and composition since 1997 have led to new assortment of relationships with both kin and non-kin. Additional behavioral experiments will be conducted at UC Davis, for cross-cultural comparison. Three primary questions will be addressed: (1) How much do people vary within groups, in knowledge, attitudes, and personality?; (2) How do people produce and understand signals of this variation?; and (3) How do people use this information to assort within groups? Evidence will come from mathematical modeling, experiments, participant observation, time allocation studies, social network structure, and content analysis of verbal interactions.

Anthropologists have long recognized the importance of so-called "ethnic markers" in signaling group membership to improve cooperative outcomes, which has recently been the focus of extensive formal modeling. Given the fluid nature of social life, however, assortment within local groups confronts a different set of problems than that between groups, which this research will address, assessing adaptations to individual variation. Further, this work investigates the significance of individual differences in generating cultural products, emphasizing the role of similarity-based preferences in interpersonal association, and uncovering the underlying signaling functions of symbolic behaviors.

This project will also make broader contributions to international collaboration and scientific training. Extensive interaction with Brazilian scholars will be facilitated at multiple universities in Brazil, strengthening ongoing associations and introducing new opportunities for collaboration. Research training and experience will also be provided to students, both in the US and in Brazil. Finally, the study of social assortment and cooperative outcomes has tremendous applied importance for the design of institutions for conservation and governance, at both local and regional scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Richard McElreath and Dr. Thomas Flamson explored the mechanisms that influence human group formation and the means through which group formation is negotiated, maintained, and reformed, a core question in anthropology's mission to theoretically explore the causes, consequences, and complexities of human social and cultural variability. As individuals vary in their goals, desires, and abilities, and successful cooperation often depends upon assortment that respects this variation, Flamson and McElreath undertook a two-year study of the formation of smaller cooperative groups within larger communities, a process often called "assortment." This research was primarily conducted in an agricultural community in Northeastern Brazil, where the changes in community membership and composition since collectivization in 1997 have led to new range of relationships with both kin and non-kin. Evidence was collected via experiments, participant observation, assays of social network structure, and content analyses of verbal interactions, presenting a range of data supporting the hypothesis that social assortment depends, in part, on assessments of dyadic similarity. In addition, innovative mathematical modeling showed the evolutionary importance of a broader category of covert signals in structuring cooperative assortment. Overall, this research has provided important answers and uncovered interesting new directions for future research in regards to the project’s three primary questions: (1) How much do people vary within groups, in knowledge, attitudes, and personality?; (2) How do people produce and understand signals of this variation?; and (3) How do people use this information to assort within groups?

Anthropologists have long recognized the importance of so-called "ethnic markers" in signaling group membership to improve cooperative outcomes, which has recently been the focus of extensive formal modeling. Given the fluid nature of social life, however, assortment within local groups confronts a different set of problems than that between groups, which this research addressed, assessing adaptations to individual variation. Further, this work investigated the significance of individual differences in generating cultural products, emphasizing the role of similarity-based preferences in interpersonal association, and uncovering the underlying signaling functions of symbolic behaviors. Finally, this project led to the development of a new methodology (“arc mapping”) for assessing social closeness in the field, where computers and widespread literacy cannot be guaranteed.

This project also made significant broader contributions to international collaboration and scientific training. Extensive interaction with Brazilian scholars took place in multiple universities in Brazil, including a number of invited talks at individual departments and international conferences, strengthening ongoing associations and introducing new opportunities for collaboration. Research training was provided to a number of Brazilian graduate students as part of an internationally collaborative content analysis. Finally, an extensive engagement in community-based research was achieved, discussing the project goals and methods with members of the research community to discover and address any concerns and ensure the community benefitted from its participation.
